stem: The nurse is preparing to perform tracheostomy suctioning for a client with copious secretions. Place the priority steps in the correct order.

options.text: Insert the catheter without suction until resistance is met.
Oxygenate and allow for a rest period between passes.
Apply intermittent suction while rotating and withdrawing the catheter.
Assess the client's lung sounds and heart rate.

rationale.correct: Safe suctioning prevents hypoxia and trauma. (1) Hyper-oxygenation builds an 'O2 reserve'. (2) Insertion without suction prevents mucosal damage. (3) Withdrawal with intermittent suction removes secretions. (4) Rest allows for re-oxygenation. (5) Final assessment verifies the effectiveness of the intervention.
rationale.incorrect: Applying continuous suction during insertion is incorrect as it causes tissue trauma and worsens hypoxia.
clinicalPearls: Suction pressure should be set between 80-120 mmHg for adults.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always remember: Never apply suction when going 'in', only when coming 'out'.

mnemonic.title: H-I-W-R-A
mnemonic.expansion: Hyper-ox, In (no suction), Withdraw (suction), Rest, Assess.

reviewUnits.heading: Airway Management: Tracheostomy Care
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must use sterile technique for open suctioning to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Monitor for bradycardia during the procedure, which indicates vagal stimulation.
